explanation.rules:
Phan Rang Cham

Syllable Structure:
Penultimate and Final Syllables: (...) D (V L) | V (C)
Monosyllabic: V
Both syllables:
{*b, *d, *g, *j} > {p, t, k, c}
NV > Nɨ
Vː > V
Penultimate syllable:
*ʔV > V
*lV > li
*bV(h)L > pɨL
otherwise, CV(V) > Ca
-h- is lost (becomes null).
Final syllable:
*s > th
Final stops *p, *t, *k -ʔ

Tsat
Finals and Tones:
Final ...h: Lost. Preceding ø becomes ø⁵⁵
Final ...ay - ...aːiʔ⁴².
Final ...aN - ...aːnʔ⁴².
Tone development from Proto-Chamic voiceless final ...T:
    Final T is lost, may become N, w, y.
    With initial voiced consonant (+D), tone becomes ʔ⁴² or ¹¹.
    Without initial voiced consonant (-D), tone becomes ʔ²⁴ or ³³.
Sound Changes by Syllable:
{*b, *p, *g} (V) {*l, *r} > {ph, p, kh}i.
Otherwise, the penultimate syllable is lost.
Final syllable:
    {*b, *d, *g}- > {ph, th, kh}-.
    *r- > z-.
    {*ow, *ey} > {ə, ai}.

Key
V: a vowel.
C: a consonant.
D: a voiced consonant (b, d, j).
T: a voiceless consonant (k, t, ʔ).
N: a nasal consonant (m, n, ŋ).
L: l or r.
